A note on factorisation of division polynomials

arXiv:math/0606684v1 [math.NT] 27 Jun 2006

D. Sadornil
Departamento of Matemáticas,U. Salamanca
Pza. de la Merced 1-4, 37008 Salamanca, Spain.
email: sadornil@usal.es
Abstract
In [2], Verdure gives the factorisation patterns of division polynomials of
elliptic curves defined over a finite field. However, the result given there contains
a mistake. In this paper, we correct it.

1

Introduction

Let p > 3 be a prime number and q a power of p. Let E be an elliptic curve over
the finite field Fq . Thus, we can assume that E has equation E : y 2 = x3 + ax + b.
The set of rational points on E, denoted by E(Fq ), has group structure. If n is an
integer, we denote by E(Fq )[n] (or E[n] if the field is the algebraic closure Fq of Fq )
the rational points of order n. If n is relatively prime with p, E[n] ∼
= Z/nZ × Z/nZ.
Let ψn (x) be the division polynomials of E (see [1]). As it is well known, the
roots of the polynomial ψn are the abscissas of the n-torsion points, that is
P = (x, y) ∈ E[n] ⇔ ψn (x) = 0.
Hence, the factorisation patterns of these polynomial give information about the
extension where the n-torsion points are defined.
The Frobenius endomorphism,
φ : E(Fq ) → E(Fq )
(x, y) → (xq , y q )
characterizes the rationality of a point of the elliptic curve as follows
∀P ∈ E(Fq ), P ∈ E(Fqn ) ⇔ φn (P ) = P.
In the paper Factorisation of division polynomials (Proc. Japan Academy, Ser
A. 80, no. 5, pp. 79-82), Verdure gives the degree and the number of factors of the
division polynomial of an elliptic curve. However, the result present there contains
a mistake. We correct it here.

2

Patterns of l-th division polynomials

Let l be an odd prime different from the characteristic of Fq . We present here the
factorisation patterns of division polynomial only when the l-torsion points generate
different extension fields (the wrong result in [2]). If all l-torsion points are defined
over the same extension field, the factorisation can be found in [2].

 Remmark 3 Verdure gives the function i(x, y) = lcm(x, y)/2 when x and y are
both even.
Proof.
We follow the proof given in [2] except for the wrong cases.
Let I be an irreducible factor ψl (x) of degree d, and P a point of l-torsion
corresponding to one of its roots, then d is the minimum positive integer n such that
φn (P ) = ±P . Let (P, Q) be a basis of E[l] as in Lemma 1. We distinguish the cases
q 6= ρ2 and q = ρ2 .
i) Suppose that q 6= ρ2 . If R is an l-torsion point which is a non-zero multiple
of P (or Q), we have that the minimum n such that φn (R) = ±R is n = h(α)
(or h(β)). Notice that, φn (R) = −R if and only if α (or β) is even, and hence
n = α/2 (or β/2).
Finally, let R be any non-zero l-torsion point not of the previous form, then
R = k(P + jQ) with 1 ≤ j, k ≤ l − 1. So, φn (R) = k(φn (P ) + jφn (Q)). The
subgroup generated by R (hRi) is rational over Fqn if and only if φn (R) = ±R.
The minimum extension where hRi is defined is Fqn , with n minimum such
that φn (R) = ±R.
It is easy to prove that φn (R) = R if and only if φn (P ) = P and φn (Q) = Q.
Hence lcm(α, β) | n and n = lcm(α, β) is the minimum.
On the other hand, φn (R) = −R, if and only if φn (P ) = −P and φn (Q) = −Q.
This is only possible when α and β are both even. Moreover, lcm(α/2, β/2) | n
and α or β not divides lcm(α/2, β/2) (if, for example, α | lcm(α/2, β/2), then
φn (P ) = P ). On the other hand, α/2 and β/2 have the same parity, otherwise,
for example, if α/2 is even and β/2 odd then lcm(α/2, β/2) = lcm(α/2, β) and
β divides lcm(α/2, β/2) which is a contradiction. If υ2 (α) = υ2 (β), then n =
lcm(α/2, β/2) is the minimum integer such that φn (P ) = −P and φn (Q) =
−Q. Otherwise, if both valuations are not equal, lcm(α/2, β/2) is divisible by
α if υ2 (α) < υ2 (β) (by β if υ2 (α) > υ2 (β)) which contradicts φn (R) = −R.
Counting the number of points of each type, namely l − 1, l − 1 and (l − 1)2 ,
we have the number of factors of each type.
ii) Suppose that q = ρ2 . A point which is a non-zero multiple of P leads to factors
of degree α or α/2 as before. If R is not a multiple of P , then in order to have
φn (R) = ±R, we have that ρn = ±1 and nρn−1 = 0. Then, depending on the
parity of α, we have n = lcm(α, l) or n = lcm(α/2, l). Finally, since α | l − 1,
it is relatively prime to l. Therefore, these values are h(α)l.

Example 4 Consider the elliptic curve y 2 = x3 + 3x + 6 over F17 and take l =
5. Then α = 2 and β = 4. According to [2], the pattern of ψ5 (x) should be
((1, 2), (2, 1), (2, 4)), but in fact it is ((1, 2), (2, 1), (4, 2)).
